title: Good is not good enough â€“ Erik ten Hag wants Man Utd to raise their standards
body_text:
Good is not good enough â€“ Erik ten Hag wants Man Utd to raise their standards
Manchester United boss Erik ten Hag has told his players â€œgood is not good enoughâ€ as he attempts to return the club to domestic and European prominence.
The Dutchman signed a two-year contract extension after guiding the club to FA Cup final glory against Manchester City at the end of last season, the second trophy of his reign.
As he gets back to work under new co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe with sporting director Dan Ashworth now on board, Ten Hag has set his sights on the Premier League title and Champions League success.
Asked if there was anything different he wanted to do in an interview with MUTV, he said: â€œA lot because we won an FA Cup, we won a Carabao Cup, but also we have high expectations from ourselves.
â€œWe know it doesnâ€™t come overnight; we have to work for it. We are highly ambitious, so we have to raise our standards day by day, and improve every day.
â€œEvery time, we have to live with the line in our head â€“ good is not good enough. We have to do better.â€
United had gone six years without a major trophy before they beat Newcastle to lift the Carabao Cup in February last year, but even Mayâ€™s 2-1 victory over neighbours City at Wembley, which he said showed the club can â€œcompete with the bestâ€, has not quenched Ten Hagâ€™s thirst for tangible success.
The club won the last of their 13 Premier League titles â€“ they have been English champions 20 times in total â€“ 11 years ago, while they last reached the pinnacle of European football in 2008.
Ten Hag said: â€œUnited didnâ€™t win, for over six years, a trophy. Now weâ€™ve won two, but we are up for more and for higher titles, like the English title and even more, like going into Europe.
â€œThatâ€™s a process that takes time, and weâ€™ll work on it. But I know with the set-up at the club, with the changes to the structure, and the changes to infrastructure here around Carrington, we will be ready for the future. We will improve.
â€œYou feel it here, it gives a new energy, it gives a new dynamic and that will help us to achieve our targets. In the short-term, it stays the same: we want to win every game, and we have seen we are capable of beating everyone.â€
The changes in infrastructure involve an ongoing Â£50million redevelopment of the clubâ€™s Carrington headquarters, to which the first players returned on Monday to be greeted by a challenge from Ten Hag.

He said: â€œIn every season after a break, you will have surprises. Weâ€™re looking forward, weâ€™re so curious: who is it this season, the surprise who can contribute to our team?
â€œLike last year, Kobbie Mainoo, Alejandro Garnacho coming up and playing a big role. They are the two goalscorers in the final. Today, we started, but which player is there who can do the same?â€
In the meantime, Mainoo and club-mate Luke Shaw will head into Euro 2024 semi-final battle with Ten Hagâ€™s native country in Dortmund on Wednesday evening.
Asked if he had spoken to the pair, he said: â€œYeah, sure. Of course, itâ€™s a fantastic game coming. Both sides are playing in the semi-finals, at the highest level. I think everyone is really excited.
â€œFootball is so important in culture in England, as it is in Holland. It will be a great match â€“ let the best win!â€
